STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 1, 2021
David Garvin
Catholic Social Services Of Washtenaw
4925 Packard Road
Ann Arbor, MI 48108-1521
RE: License #: CB810201018
Catholic Social Services Of Washtenaw
4925 Packard Road
Ann Arbor, MI 48108-1521
Dear Mr. Garvin:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 1/27/2021.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations
please identify why the previous CAP was not successful and what
changes will be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, why the prior CAP failed to achieve compliance.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
One of three foster home files did not have current first aid/CPR training. The most
recent training on file was from September 2018.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(2) The borrowing agency is responsible for securing the items
identified in subrules (1) (d), (e), (g), (h), and (i) of this rule
annually for the duration of the child's placement.
One of one borrowed bed files did not have an updated Foster Parent Agency
Agreement for 2020 as required by this rule.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following: (ii) A dental reexamination shall
be obtained at least every 18 months unless a greater
frequency is indicated.
One of three foster care files did not have a current dental exam. The last dental on
file was from 12/13/18.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
4

One of three foster care files did not have a home visit completed for September
2020.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child.
One of three foster care files did not have an initial placement outline to document
the requirements of this rule.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 801 Health Services For Children In Foster Care
Pages 14-15
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents if the child is a temporary court ward. Quarterly.
At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
5

Three of three foster care files did not meet this requirement:
File One: No medical passports were on file for the period under review.
File Two: Missing quarterly updated passports from May and August 2020.
File Three: Medical passport was not provided to foster parent at placement.
Quarterly updated passports were missing for May and August 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
Renewal dated 8/12/19, 1st provisional recommendation, CAP approved 10/24/19.
Renewal dates 2/10/20, CAP approved 2/25/20.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care- Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS
office designee.
CI 17-099
When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from all
appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and older for
foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile justice, should
be obtained before the corresponding court hearing. All treatment
plans with a report date of August 1, 2017, or later must have
signatures from all appropriate case members within 30 days of
the report date.
Three of three foster care files did not meet this requirement:
File One: 3/20/20 PATP signed 10/12/20; 6/15/20 PATP signed 10/12/20.
File Two: 4/17/20 PATP signed late by the parent on 12/12/20; 4/18/20 PATP signed
10/20/20; 7/17/20 and 10/15/20 PATPs are unsigned by the parent and foster
parent.
File Three: 5/28/20 PATP signed late by the foster parent on 1/12/21; 8/26/20 PATP
signed 10/26/20; 11/23/20 PATP signed 1/11/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
Renewal dated 8/12/19, 1st provisional recommendation, CAP approved 10/24/19.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
 Case Plan Reassessment (USP) Within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
6

One of three foster care files did not hold an FTM within 30 days prior to the 6/15/20
USP.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
Renewal dated 8/12/19, 1st provisional recommendation, CAP approved 10/24/19.
Renewal dates 2/10/20, CAP approved 2/25/20.
FOM 722-09 Updated Service Plan
Supervisory approval- prior to finalizing, the USP along with the
required assessments (FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed and
approved by the foster care supervisor only after a face-to-face
meeting with the worker. Case service plan approval process
requires the foster care supervisor to review and approve the USP
within 14 calendar days of the report date.
One of three foster care cases (one of eleven USPs) was not approved within the
required timeframe. The 8/26/20 USP was not approved until 10/1/20.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
Renewal dated 8/12/19, 1st provisional recommendation, CAP approved 10/24/19.
FOM 722-08E Foster Care Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile
Justice Action Summary, and upload to MiSACWIS within the
timeframe required for the specified action/change:
Page 3- Prior to a planned placement change, or within three
business days of an emergency placement change, the
caseworker must document…
Page 6- Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile
justice program/case closure, the caseworker must document…
One of three open cases and three of three closed cases were missing a DHHS-69.
File One (open): A DHHS-69 was not completed for a move on 2/5/20.
File Two (closed): A DHHS-69 was not completed at case closure.
File Three (closed): A DHHS-69 was not completed at case closure.
File Four (closed): A DHHS-69 was completed at case closure. However, it was not
completed within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
Renewal dated 8/12/19, 1st provisional recommendation, CAP approved 10/24/19.
7

IV. ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns were identified by the DCWL analyst.
V. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following area:
One foster home file held a special evaluation (SE) that was initiated concurrently
with the child moving from the home. At the conclusion of the SE the agency did not
provide a copy of the report to the foster care worker for that child, as he was no
longer in the home. The rule states at the conclusion of the SE the agency is
required to provide a copy to any worker that “has children placed in the home”. The
agency was advised that best practice would be to provide the report to the worker
of the child that moved, as the child was in the home at the time of the allegation,
and the allegation was specifically about that child.
VI. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
VII. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
A CAP was approved on 10/24/19 as a result of the renewal evaluation in which a 1st
Provisional license was recommended. A second CAP was approved on 2/25/20 as
a result of the renewal evaluation in which a regular license was recommended.
During the current review, the agency was determined to have demonstrated
significant improvement in several areas. In 2019 there were 48 violations cited; in
2020 there were 13 violations cited; in the current review there were 10 violations
cited. In addition, the occurrence of violations has also decreased. Most violations
from this current review were found in only one of three files reviewed. Over the past
year, the agency has hired additional staff, and implemented new procedures and
tracking mechanisms. These steps appear to be working. However, it is noted that
the agency still has some work to do regarding action summaries, medical
passports, and PATP signatures.
8

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
January 28, 2021
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 1, 2021
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
9
